instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1465: What is A1465? A1465 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2924, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00164, 820-3208, 820-3435..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWR: What is ALL_SYS_PWR? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS_PWR, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWD: What is ALL_SYS_PWD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS_PWD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
Hi 

I've got another mac air in at the moment  Coffee damage.  Sugared too.

the whole backlight area is nasty.  Fuse blown.  I've replaced that and the green light goes nicely to orange.  But fan stays at high speed throughout. 

No power in the backlight circuit.  Looks like there's no signal on <SIGNAL>LCD_BCKLT_EN</SIGNAL> but there is 8v on <SIGNAL>LCD_BCKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR>. Is that normal?

some of the coils appear shorted to ground - L7100, L7720 and L7630  and every other coil towards the fan;  and <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is getting hot to touch.  all are at about 45C.  

any thoughts on chasing down the short?  alcohol test does not show anything particularly hotter than other things.  likewise an infrared heat scan (with a gun).  

thanks
Justin

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
You have a display connected??
What is the resistance to ground on L7720?
Fan at high speed is a sensor failure, also if trackpad is not connected....

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
thanks aprendiz

resistance to ground over L7720 is approx. 13MOhm.  

no display connected.  Board is bare, so no keyboard, trackpad etc.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
Plugged a screen in .

The laptop boots to bios but <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> gets very hot. 

L7720 seem to vary in resistance to ground . Now around 13k.  

L7630 is still close to zero ohms to ground .  L7330 is a little better at about 1k .

I've prodded at most things that seem like a culprit and I'm not finding any bad caps or similar . None of the passives are getting super hot.   And I get the boot chime (no SSD so no OS . I will create a usb boot drive tomorrow).  

Is this likely to be a bad <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>?  If so, I guess the board is a write off?  Or is it worth trying some heat on it?

Separately the screen connector started smoking around the backlight pins.  So I guess that wasn't as salvageable as i had originally hoped. It cleaned up nicely but probably was shorted inside. I've removed it now . The backlight pins of the cable have lost their copper but the underlying metal is still good.  The resistance to ground didn't change after removing the connector.  

The fuse went. So that's one positive!

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
just following up on this.  the laptop continues to power up but a couple of power rails seem odd.  notably 

PP18v5 is at 14.8v rather than the stated 18.5v (this feels like an error in the schematic...) ; and
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 3.3v rather than 3v.  
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is at 0.8v rather than 1.25 and
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> is also at 0.8v rather than 1.05.

I poured some mild heat on to <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> and the coil resistances are now:

L7630  16Ohm

L7330  820 Ohm

L7110 20 Ohm

L7510  5Ohm
L7550  4Ohm

Any hints on where to search next? 

many thanks
Justin

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> normally gets quite warm, but you should be able to keep your finger on it.

LCD connector needs to be replaced now and also the LCD cable. This is the reason why you use a cracked trash LCD for testing.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
LCD connector is removed.  I'm waiting for new connectors so can't test with a different screen yet.  

But the voltages on ppvcore still seem wrong . I've removed some of the coils and injected voltage into that rail directly but nothing gets hot.   

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
This thing was turning on with an image and you are injecting voltage on CPU Vcore? :(

Does it even still chime now?

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
No idea about the image . The display connector was fubar.  

Chiming normally.  But low voltages on the 1.25 and 1.05 rails. High voltage on the 3v rail and top speed fan.   

I've put it to the side until the connectors arrive . Loads of public holidays in France at the moment so deliveries are few are sparse .

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
It chimes so board is fine. Replace LCD connector and LCD cable. If you insert the fried LCD cable it will burn your connector again.
This is why you need a cracked LCD for testing this stuff.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
Thanks

I've got a few screens now .

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹ fingers crossed that connectors will arrive early in the week .

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
replaced the lcd connector and plugged the fan etc back in.  Spun up the first time then stopped and now will no longer spin.  

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> still getting very hot to touch.  not something I'd like to keep my finger on (and hotter than comparable machines).  

Gut feel is that there is still a short somewhere in this board but nothing is getting hot other than <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.  

Any ideas?  

thanks
Justin

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: You mean <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>? Is that getting hot without the fan spinning up?

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
yes <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> gets hot without fan spin.  

the fan 'jolts'.  rocks on its spindle.  

there is voltage on the fan pins though.  is this a case of a broken fan ?!!

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
nope.  nothing on PPVCORE.

14.4v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.

the other rails are mostly there but:

I'm not getting 1.8v at all the points that it should be present.  for example - there is nothing at <RESISTOR>R2719</RESISTOR> but <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> is fully provided.

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>:  1.35v 
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>;  1.35v  (but <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.5v)
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> : 0.675v
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>:  0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_SO_CPU</SIGNAL>: 39mV
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 76mV
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_LDO</SIGNAL>:  1.05v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and AXG: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>: 1.35v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL>: 1.8v

If I've not included a rail then it is reading OK.  I have not checked the TBT rails.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
[LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px]the 1v8 issue was measurement error.  It is present (1.78 - 1.80) in all the right places.  [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

[LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px]I had some spare time so probed some of the main caps around the coils.  <CAPACITOR>C1768</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1680</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1683</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C1682</CAPACITOR> (PPVCore caps)  all have very low resistance (4-15Ohms).  I'll have to chase this through.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: Is there an easy way to isolate the core so that I can safely inject current into those rails?

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
the reason you're reading low resistance on CPU core voltage is that it has CPU installed. CPU is basically your short unless its dead.
CPU/GPU has very low resistance between power rail and ground, this is absolutely normal. just play a little bit with the numbers: CPU eats, say, 20W. now divide it by CPU voltage, this would be your current. now divide voltage by current and this is your resistance, 10-20 ohm, yup, multimeter CT will beep, "ahaa! we have a short here!"... nope.
Also, in "shorted circuit" conditions you can't really test capacitors without desoldering them.
wrong voltage does not necessarily means short circuit. maybe one phase does not work, maybe one of the CPU Power MosFETs failed, maybe one of the mosfet drivers failed, maybe CPU asks for the wrong voltage for some reason.
but it's all does not matter since your board chimes. brain-dead boards do not chime. board needs CPU to run the bios as well is to decode and play the audio file.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
thanks.  I think that a resistance across a cap in that area that low seems wrong though.  Are you saying that you get similar readings on a known good board?  

this one has stopped chiming.  corrosion in the intervening period perhaps.  Or a shorted cap (which is my bet).

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
this is not "across cap" resistance, this is net resistance of all components between your probes. the only right way to test capacitor is to desolder it.
the only stuff besides voltages you can really test with MM in circuit are low resistors or fuses. caps could be tested with an oscilloscope on working board but you need this only for electrolitic ones since they are known to fade.
i am working primarly on PC Notebook boards, so sometimes i have an priveledge of removable CPU :cool:
so yup, 5-10 ohms on GPU or CPU power line is absolutely normal for working board, no mater which board it is. it is also normal to have "low resistance" on RAM. if something takes 1 Amp current, sucking 1.3 volts, it will and it should "beep" on continiuity test.

once again: if you [I]had [/I]chime, CPU Voltage rail [I]was [/I]almost surely ok. if it's dead now after playig with it, i guess you killed something like voltage sence or power driver on this line.
if you have a water damage with an ongoing corrosion, the first step was to stop it, then troubleshoot its consequences. i hope you did it, so it should be out of the table.
voltage injection is not a magic trick for everything, it should be applied only when the short circuit is obvious but hard to find.

bierf example:
you have a short on high side mosfet of the CPU Circuit, you inject the voltage right to the V+ rail somewhere. hello, your entire CPU power system is probably dead now since you gave higher voltage to the low voltage line. capacitors will be killed one by one: you inject voltage, you see some heat on one, you remove it, aha, now the next one is dead, then you end up with the dead voltage sence, dead feedback, dead driver (since mosfets usually short between all terminals, not just drain and source), dead caps, and dead CPU if your LPS is strong enough.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
Thanks.  I found a dead cap.  Removed it and the mosfet chip and now have another rail back and the cap is behaving itself with normal increasing resistance when measured. 

But still no fan spin or vcore.  Time for sleep and I will investigate more tomorrow .

The chime was there after I finished checking a couple of weeks ago, alhougg the board was gettng super hot.  The board has not been touched since.  So something has degraded in the meantime .

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
current status is that I have my <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> rail back now.
I'm getting 1.5v on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> but only 1.35v on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>.  which is confusing.

and still low voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>, zip on <SIGNAL>PP0V75_SO_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>
and nothing on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>/AXG

I guess the next thing to investigate is the 150mv drop on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>?

ideas?

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
in fact I'm going to hunt on the ppvcore instead.  

no high on the en line to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.  putting 5v in to that got fan spin.  

so no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGOOD</SIGNAL>.

the slight flummox now is that per my schematic I am missing both <RESISTOR>R7962</RESISTOR> and â€¦ <CHIP>U7960</CHIP> (ISL).  pads are present for both; and the resistor ladder for <SIGNAL>PWR_GOODS</SIGNAL> is there and half populated.

I guess I must have the wrong schematic and/or boardview (although everything else is right so far...).  how annoying.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
I have a board that was pre ISL and uses BJT to provide <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. not enough coffee.

but still no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>!

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: If there is no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> there will not be Vcore. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> must be present first. Check all rails and see which one is missing. Vcore should come on as soon as <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is present.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is made from <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> which takes input from:

1.  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_MON</SIGNAL> via a resistor divider.  I get 3.3v coming in but the resistor divider is a different ratio to what's in the schematic.  I get 0.77v at the divider and 0.7v at the pin.  From the schematic I should be getting more than 1.05v at the divider.  

2.  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_VMON</SIGNAL>.  I get 1.35v here and 0.78v at the pin.  This is higher than the stated worst threshold.

3. <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SO_VMON</SIGNAL>.  I get 1.05v where it should be and 0.78v at the pin again.  Higher than the worst case threshold.

so the odd one out is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO_MON</SIGNAL> via the resistor divider.  

For the resistor divider I measure 
<RESISTOR>R7951</RESISTOR> at 9,4kOhm

<RESISTOR>R7952</RESISTOR> at 6.1kOhms

so a divider ration of 0.39  

whereas it should be 0.33.  

on the collector of Q1 I am seeing on 200mV despite having 3.3v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

so I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and I'm now seeing the right voltages on the pads.  So I guess that <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> was fried?  is that a reasonable assumption?

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: Does anyone know a European source of ASMCC0179?  I can't even find a datasheet for it, let alone a vendor.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: Donor board, this part is used on pretty much every Apple board. Do I think it is really bad....no. I have seen it once.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: Thanks . I wasnt able to find the same part on the donor boards I checked. I will look again.

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message:
Going back to your comment about it being an unlikely culprit; these are the symptoms:

1. no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWR</SIGNAL> gd.
2. dummy <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and the board spins up.
3. voltages on all the input pins to the chip are pulled down from where they should be.  Remove the chip and all the voltages are correct at the pins.  

given the chip design, doesn't this suggest an internal short across some of the bases?  that would also stop the bases from rising high enough to turn on the transistors and thus the mosfet.  If there were a short on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWD</SIGNAL> gd after the mosfet then we shouldn't see the issues across the bases of the transistors would we?  

If this is not the culprit, can you point me towards others?  the <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> line on this board (the BJT version) is quite simple so I couldn't think of anything else!

threads.title: Mac Air 2012 - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 820 3208A
threads.message: Every board has ASMCC0179: 3115, 2915, 3437, 00165, 3536, all of them.
